metadata.author: HBL Content
metadata.summary: The document outlines the Schedule of Bank Charges by HBL for various services from July 1, 2019, to December 31, 2019. Key services and charges include: Fund Transfers: Different fee structures based on transfer amounts (ranging from Rs. 7 to Rs. 475 per transaction for both small (Rs. 1 – Rs. 200) and large amounts (up to Rs. 50,000). Cash Withdrawals: Fees at agent locations using Konnect by HBL, ranging from Rs. 7 to Rs. 325 per transaction based on the withdrawal amount. Money Transfers (IBFT): Charges for transferring money to other bank accounts through Konnect by HBL or CNIC, varying by amount. HBL Core Banking Account Transfers: Transaction fees based on the amount, from Rs. 25 to Rs. 225. Courier and Swift Charges: For local, intercity, and foreign correspondence, with charges for LCs and guarantees, as well as swift messages ranging from Rs. 100 to Rs. 1,500. Investment Banking & IPS Services: Negotiable fees, out-of-pocket expenses, and succession, arrangement, and advisory fees for services under investment and IPS. Government Business: Charges for Letters of Credit (LC) for government imports at concessional rates. The document also highlights fees for services such as mobile account opening, airtime top-up, balance inquiries, and cash deposits at agent locations, with some services being free of charge.

metadata.summary: The document outlines the Schedule of Bank Charges by HBL for various services from July 1, 2019, to December 31, 2019. Key services and charges include: Fund Transfers: Different fee structures based on transfer amounts (ranging from Rs. 7 to Rs. 475 per transaction for both small (Rs. 1 – Rs. 200) and large amounts (up to Rs. 50,000). Cash Withdrawals: Fees at agent locations using Konnect by HBL, ranging from Rs. 7 to Rs. 325 per transaction based on the withdrawal amount. Money Transfers (IBFT): Charges for transferring money to other bank accounts through Konnect by HBL or CNIC, varying by amount. HBL Core Banking Account Transfers: Transaction fees based on the amount, from Rs. 25 to Rs. 225. Courier and Swift Charges: For local, intercity, and foreign correspondence, with charges for LCs and guarantees, as well as swift messages ranging from Rs. 100 to Rs. 1,500. Investment Banking & IPS Services: Negotiable fees, out-of-pocket expenses, and succession, arrangement, and advisory fees for services under investment and IPS. Government Business: Charges for Letters of Credit (LC) for government imports at concessional rates. The document also highlights fees for services such as mobile account opening, airtime top-up, balance inquiries, and cash deposits at agent locations, with some services being free of charge.

metadata.title: SCHEDULE OF BANK CHARGES FOR THE PERIOD FROM 01.07.2019 TO 31.12.2019 - English
metadata.file_name: SCHEDULE OF BANK CHARGES FOR THE PERIOD FROM 01.07.2019 TO 31.12.2019 - English.pdf
metadata.author: HBL Content
metadata.summary: The document outlines the Schedule of Bank Charges by HBL for various services from July 1, 2019, to December 31, 2019. Key services and charges include: Fund Transfers: Different fee structures based on transfer amounts (ranging from Rs. 7 to Rs. 475 per transaction for both small (Rs. 1 – Rs. 200) and large amounts (up to Rs. 50,000). Cash Withdrawals: Fees at agent locations using Konnect by HBL, ranging from Rs. 7 to Rs. 325 per transaction based on the withdrawal amount. Money Transfers (IBFT): Charges for transferring money to other bank accounts through Konnect by HBL or CNIC, varying by amount. HBL Core Banking Account Transfers: Transaction fees based on the amount, from Rs. 25 to Rs. 225. Courier and Swift Charges: For local, intercity, and foreign correspondence, with charges for LCs and guarantees, as well as swift messages ranging from Rs. 100 to Rs. 1,500. Investment Banking & IPS Services: Negotiable fees, out-of-pocket expenses, and succession, arrangement, and advisory fees for services under investment and IPS. Government Business: Charges for Letters of Credit (LC) for government imports at concessional rates. The document also highlights fees for services such as mobile account opening, airtime top-up, balance inquiries, and cash deposits at agent locations, with some services being free of charge.

metadata.author: HBL Content
metadata.summary: The document outlines the Schedule of Bank Charges by HBL for various services from July 1, 2019, to December 31, 2019. Key services and charges include: Fund Transfers: Different fee structures based on transfer amounts (ranging from Rs. 7 to Rs. 475 per transaction for both small (Rs. 1 – Rs. 200) and large amounts (up to Rs. 50,000). Cash Withdrawals: Fees at agent locations using Konnect by HBL, ranging from Rs. 7 to Rs. 325 per transaction based on the withdrawal amount. Money Transfers (IBFT): Charges for transferring money to other bank accounts through Konnect by HBL or CNIC, varying by amount. HBL Core Banking Account Transfers: Transaction fees based on the amount, from Rs. 25 to Rs. 225. Courier and Swift Charges: For local, intercity, and foreign correspondence, with charges for LCs and guarantees, as well as swift messages ranging from Rs. 100 to Rs. 1,500. Investment Banking & IPS Services: Negotiable fees, out-of-pocket expenses, and succession, arrangement, and advisory fees for services under investment and IPS. Government Business: Charges for Letters of Credit (LC) for government imports at concessional rates. The document also highlights fees for services such as mobile account opening, airtime top-up, balance inquiries, and cash deposits at agent locations, with some services being free of charge.

Key services and charges include: Fund Transfers: Different fee structures based on transfer amounts (ranging from Rs. 7 to Rs. 475 per transaction for both small (Rs. 1 – Rs. 200) and large amounts (up to Rs. 50,000). Cash Withdrawals: Fees at agent locations using Konnect by HBL, ranging from Rs. 7 to Rs. 325 per transaction based on the withdrawal amount. Money Transfers (IBFT): Charges for transferring money to other bank accounts through Konnect by HBL or CNIC, varying by amount. HBL Core Banking Account Transfers: Transaction fees based on the amount, from Rs. 25 to Rs. 225. Courier and Swift Charges: For local, intercity, and foreign correspondence, with charges for LCs and guarantees, as well as swift messages ranging from Rs. 100 to Rs. 1,500. Investment Banking & IPS Services: Negotiable fees, out-of-pocket expenses, and succession, arrangement, and advisory fees for services under investment and IPS. Government Business: Charges for Letters of Credit (LC) for government imports at concessional rates. The document also highlights fees for services such as mobile account opening, airtime top-up, balance inquiries, and cash deposits at agent locations, with some services being free of charge.

metadata.author: HBL Content
metadata.summary: The document outlines the Schedule of Bank Charges by HBL for various services from July 1, 2019, to December 31, 2019. Key services and charges include: Fund Transfers: Different fee structures based on transfer amounts (ranging from Rs. 7 to Rs. 475 per transaction for both small (Rs. 1 – Rs. 200) and large amounts (up to Rs. 50,000). Cash Withdrawals: Fees at agent locations using Konnect by HBL, ranging from Rs. 7 to Rs. 325 per transaction based on the withdrawal amount. Money Transfers (IBFT): Charges for transferring money to other bank accounts through Konnect by HBL or CNIC, varying by amount. HBL Core Banking Account Transfers: Transaction fees based on the amount, from Rs. 25 to Rs. 225. Courier and Swift Charges: For local, intercity, and foreign correspondence, with charges for LCs and guarantees, as well as swift messages ranging from Rs. 100 to Rs. 1,500. Investment Banking & IPS Services: Negotiable fees, out-of-pocket expenses, and succession, arrangement, and advisory fees for services under investment and IPS. Government Business: Charges for Letters of Credit (LC) for government imports at concessional rates. The document also highlights fees for services such as mobile account opening, airtime top-up, balance inquiries, and cash deposits at agent locations, with some services being free of charge.

metadata.title: Soft Skills
metadata.file_name: Soft Skills.pdf
metadata.author: HBL Content
metadata.summary: This section emphasizes the importance of active listening in effective communication, particularly for phone banking officers. Key points include: Active Listening Understanding Customer Needs: Active listening helps comprehend customer concerns and demonstrates a willingness to assist. Encouraging Dialogue: Allow customers to express themselves without interruption and clarify their main issues through reflective listening and probing questions. Tips for Phone Banking Officers Opening Greetings: Start with a friendly introduction. Offer Help: Show readiness to assist right away. Listen Carefully: Pay close attention to customer inquiries. Speak Confidently: Maintain a strong voice tone that is firm yet friendly. Further Probe: Repeat information back to confirm understanding.Provide Solutions: Offer clear solutions to the customer's issues. Confirm Satisfaction: Ensure the customer is satisfied with the response. T-Pin Generation: Offer to generate a T-Pin if calling from a registered number. Call Transfer for Survey: Direct the call for customer feedback. Closing Greeting: End with a warm closing statement. Additional Call Tips Highlight Understanding: Make it clear to customers that their needs are understood.Be Courteous: Use polite language and show respect. Name Importance: Ask for and correctly pronounce the customer’s name. Go the Extra Mile: Provide more than just the minimum service. Ask, Don’t Demand: Use questions to create a collaborative atmosphere. Empower Customers: Provide information that helps them make informed choices Be Proactive: Take initiative in addressing customer needs. Avoid Jargon: Use clear and concise language, steering clear of technical terms or acronyms. This summary captures the essence of effective call handling skills that enhance customer service experiences.

full_text: Call Handling Skills Active listening is essential for effective communication. It allows for a better understanding of the customers’ needs and shows a willingness to help. Allow the customer to talk without interruption, reflect back their main question or concern and ask clarifying questions when necessary. Active Listening: TIPS FOR PHONE BANKING OFFICER 1. Opening greetings & introduction of yourself. 2. Offer to help 3. Listen Carefully 4. Speak Confidently (voice Tone should be high/but not aggressive). 5. Further Probe-repeat the information to ensure you got it right. 6. Provide the Solution 7. Confirm Satisfaction 8. Offer T-pin generation (If customer is calling from registered Number ). 9. Call Transfer to Customer Survey. 10. Closing Greeting TIPS TO USE DURING A CALL. ➢ Highlight Understanding  Be Courteous  Important is My NAME  Extra Mile  Ask, don’t demand  Empower  Be proactive  Jargons and language 6 • Highlight Understanding Ensure that each customer is aware that you understood their needs. By using active listening techniques and asking relevant questions, you will communicate that you understand them and are making an effort to help solve their problem. 7 • Be Courteous Be polite and have respect for your customers. Always use “please” and “thank you” and create an inviting environment for the customers. 8 • Important is My NAME Ask the customer their name and pronounce it correctly. This communicates respect for the customer and lets them know that they are important. 9 • Extra Mile Demonstrate through actions that the customer is important by giving more than the minimum effort required. By taking the initiative to provide better service or give the customer something extra, customers will feel valued and appreciated. 10 • Ask, don’t demand Statements can sound harsh. Asking appropriate questions makes the conversation more collaborative. 11 • Empower Empower customers with adequate information to make informed decisions. When there are options, thoroughly describe each available alternative. By offering choices, customers will be more involved in solving their problems. This results in a higher level of customer satisfaction. 12 • Be proactive Engage in proactive steps to satisfy the customer’s needs. Being proactive will also help to reduce barriers when problem solving. 13 • Jargons and language Avoid technical terms, jargon and acronyms. Be professional, concise and clear. 14 15
